answers.answer: I see no reason to test again, and perhaps you are getting something else on your lips, like dermatitis, cheilitis, etc.If you get a sore again, see your doc to have it cultured.AJ

Thanks for the response, I decided I will get the fever blister cultured if and when it shows up again.How does someone pose the questions to Dr. H Hunter Handsfield? Does he just jump in on this discussion?

No, he doesn't jump in here.Click on forums at the top of the page.  The experts forums are listed on the right side of the page.  Click on stds.Then click the green "post a question", and it will take you through the process.Can I suggest that you read through other questions already posted there?  It will save you the $15, and I think you will get answers that you need.AJ

Thanks Aj ,I've read related posts so I'll forgo the consult with Dr H, I'm pretty much up to speed on the tests but nothing addresses my confusion on the neg type 1 results with an obvious fever blister over the years or if being older with bad habits might require testing down the road.Thank you for your time AJ.

Well, perhaps your hsv test wasn't accurate on the hsv1 part.  The IgG doesn't pick up about 10% of hsv1 infections.I'm not sure what you mean by future testing.  All of your hsv2 tests are negative, and you would have had a positive test by now.Aj

question: Two questions actually. First off, I had some itch, cuts, and thickening of the vulva which started 2 weeks after unprotected sex with a new person so I had the HSV-2 type specific antibody test at 7 weeks, 13 1/2 weeks 22 1/2 weeks and 29 1/2 weeks all of which came back negative, results were respectively .08, .06, .03 and .04. All of these are obviously negative.So at 22 1/2 and 29 1/2 weeks I had my doctor order the HSV-1 also. Those results were respectively, ,04 and .31, again, obviously negative. I am 49 years old, rarely get colds or the flu because I'm not exposed to being in public often and rarely ever get sick when someone else in the household is. I also have no illnesses of any kind like diabetes or anything else but I am a life long smoker (no lectures please) and drink at least 2 alcoholic beverages a day.My second concern is that over the past 25+ years I have had what I thought were a single fever blister on my chin approximately every three years and expected to at least test positive for type 1 and two tests have come up negative.So the questions are:1. Should I continue to test for both Type 1 and 2, if so how long?2. If my fever blister isn't HSV what could it be or are the results wrong?This discussion is related tohttp://www.medhelp.org/posts/show/248831.
title: If not HSV then what?
